articles.headline: Confronting a Law Of Limits
articles.snippet: Apple is so big that it’s running up against the law of large numbers, which suggests that the fast rise of its shares and earnings will slow.
articles.abstract: Apple is so big that it’s running up against the law of large numbers, which suggests that the fast rise of its shares and earnings will slow.
articles.lead_paragraph: These days, it’s hard to find a superlative that adequately describes Apple. But maybe simplest is best: biggest.

articles.headline: Why It’s So Hard to Transfer Cash to Your Friends
articles.snippet: Three big banks join forces to create a person-to-person electronic payments service that still has problems, but you’ll have to pay for the privilege to use it.
articles.abstract: Three big banks join forces to create a person-to-person electronic payments service that still has problems, but you’ll have to pay for the privilege to use it.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, at a dinner with a dozen or so friends, the check arrived and the usual payment scrum ensued, with cash being passed back and forth across the table.

articles.headline: Rents Keep Rising, Even as Housing Prices Fall
articles.snippet: With few rental buildings erected over the last few years, available units are going fast, with the nationwide vacancy rate at its lowest level in more than a decade.
articles.abstract: With few rental buildings erected over the last few years, available units are going fast, with the nationwide vacancy rate at its lowest level in more than a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: The housing market remains a potent drag on the economy as home prices continue to slip, foreclosed homes fill some neighborhoods and millions of construction workers scramble for jobs.

articles.headline: Web Deals Cheer Hollywood, Despite Drop in Moviegoers
articles.snippet: Movie attendance hit a 16-year low in 2011. Star wattage continues to dim. DVD sales keep plunging. But Hollywood has a noticeable spring in its step.
articles.abstract: Movie attendance hit a 16-year low in 2011. Star wattage continues to dim. DVD sales keep plunging. But Hollywood has a noticeable spring in its step.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Movie attendance hit a 16-year low in 2011. Star wattage continues to dim. DVD sales keep plunging. Almost none of the films being honored at Sunday’s Academy Awards have struck a mainstream nerve.

articles.headline: U.S. Agencies See No Move by Iran to Build a Bomb
articles.snippet: At the center of the debate is the question of Iran’s ultimate ambitions, and despite a new report claiming that Iran has accelerated its uranium enrichment program, American analysts said there is no hard evidence of plans to build a nuclear bomb...
articles.abstract: At the center of the debate is the question of Iran’s ultimate ambitions, and despite a new report claiming that Iran has accelerated its uranium enrichment program, American analysts said there is no hard evidence of plans to build a nuclear bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog said in a new report Friday that Iran had accelerated its uranium enrichment program, American intelligence analysts continue to believe that there is no hard evidence that Iran has decided to build a nuclear bomb.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Branding a Soldier With ‘Personality Disorder’
articles.snippet: The case of Capt. Susan Carlson has raised questions about whether the Pentagon uses a psychiatric diagnosis to eject troops it considers troublesome or to deny them benefits.
articles.abstract: The case of Capt. Susan Carlson has raised questions about whether the Pentagon uses a psychiatric diagnosis to eject troops it considers troublesome or to deny them benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Capt. Susan Carlson was not a typical recruit when she volunteered for the Army in 2006 at the age of 50. But the Army desperately needed behavioral health professionals like her, so it signed her up.

articles.headline: Settlements Without Admissions Get Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Allowing companies and individuals to settle federal regulatory charges without admitting that they actually did anything wrong is an entrenched practice, one that is increasingly criticized.
articles.abstract: Allowing companies and individuals to settle federal regulatory charges without admitting that they actually did anything wrong is an entrenched practice, one that is increasingly criticized.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The entrenched practice of allowing companies and individuals to settle federal regulatory charges without admitting that they actually did anything wrong is coming under growing scrutiny by the courts.

articles.headline: 2 U.S. Officers Slain; Advisers to Exit Kabul Ministries
articles.snippet: The Afghan government said it had identified a suspect in the shooting of two American officers inside the Interior Ministry building in Kabul.
articles.abstract: The Afghan government said it had identified a suspect in the shooting of two American officers inside the Interior Ministry building in Kabul.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two American officers were shot dead inside the Interior Ministry building here on Saturday, and NATO responded by immediately pulling all its advisers out of Afghan ministries in Kabul, in a deepening of the crisis over the American military’s burning of Korans at a NATO military base.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Broken Trust in God’s Country
articles.snippet: In eastern Ohio, Amish and Mennonite communities grapple with questions of faith and finance as a neighbor stands accused of a Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: In eastern Ohio, Amish and Mennonite communities grapple with questions of faith and finance as a neighbor stands accused of a Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUGARCREEK, Ohio

articles.headline: Moral Hazard: A Tempest-Tossed Idea
articles.snippet: As an economic concept, “moral hazard” means that people are apt to take undue risks if they don’t have to bear the consequences. But it’s also part of the debate on the limits of self-reliance.
articles.abstract: As an economic concept, “moral hazard” means that people are apt to take undue risks if they don’t have to bear the consequences. But it’s also part of the debate on the limits of self-reliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE reports outraged America: In the wake of Hurricane Katrina, people who fled the ravaged Gulf Coast were spending disaster relief, paid for by taxpayers, on tattoos, $800 handbags and trips to topless bars.

articles.headline: Prolonged Race Forces Romney Campaign to Recalibrate
articles.snippet: As Mitt Romney’s presidential effort steps up fund-raising to meet rising costs, some Republicans are worried about the impact of an extended party contest on the November election.
articles.abstract: As Mitt Romney’s presidential effort steps up fund-raising to meet rising costs, some Republicans are worried about the impact of an extended party contest on the November election.
articles.lead_paragraph: TROY, Mich. — Whether Mitt Romney wins or loses the Michigan and Arizona primaries on Tuesday, his advisers are warning donors and other supporters to prepare for a longer, more bruising and more expensive fight for the Republican presidential nomination that may not be settled until at least May.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Go Directly, Digitally to Jail? Classic Toys Learn New Clicks
articles.snippet: The evolution of classic toys and games is beginning to reflect the fact that even young children are wedded to digital devices.
articles.abstract: The evolution of classic toys and games is beginning to reflect the fact that even young children are wedded to digital devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Generation after generation, Monopoly money stacked up in piles of pink, green and gold, Hot Wheels raced across floors and Barbie was, well, just a doll.

articles.headline: Fine Line Between ‘Super PACs’ and Campaigns
articles.snippet: In practice, super PACs have become a way for candidates to bypass contribution limits by steering rich donors to ostensibly independent groups that function almost as adjuncts of the campaigns.
articles.abstract: In practice, super PACs have become a way for candidates to bypass contribution limits by steering rich donors to ostensibly independent groups that function almost as adjuncts of the campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign needs advice on direct mail strategies for reaching voters, it looks to TargetPoint Consulting. And when the independent “super PAC” supporting him needs voter research, it, too, goes to TargetPoint.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire and Michael Luo

articles.headline: Syrian Conflict Poses the Risk of Wider Strife
articles.snippet: Unlike the revolts in Libya and other Arab nations, the Syrian conflict has the potential to draw in other countries in the region and beyond.
articles.abstract: Unlike the revolts in Libya and other Arab nations, the Syrian conflict has the potential to draw in other countries in the region and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — More than a year after it began, the Arab awakening has had its seasons. After a world-shaking spring, then on through summer, autumn and winter, one country after another — Tunisia, Egypt, Libya, Yemen — has toppled autocrats, with varying amounts of blood. Some governments have stamped out revolts, like Bahrain. Others have tried modest reforms, like Morocco, or idled on the sidelines (think Algeria and Saudi Arabia).

articles.headline: Europe Gets Ready for Round 2 of Bank Loans
articles.snippet: Analysts are watching with interest this week’s reoffering of three-year loans at a rock-bottom interest rate.
articles.abstract: Analysts are watching with interest this week’s reoffering of three-year loans at a rock-bottom interest rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Central bankers do not like anyone to see them sweat, much less panic. But last November the temperature was clearly rising inside the battleship-gray office tower in downtown Frankfurt that houses the European Central Bank.

articles.headline: Risk and Riches in User Data for Facebook
articles.snippet: Facebook faces intense scrutiny on how it handles user data, creating a cloud of uncertainty for the company before its public offering.
articles.abstract: Facebook faces intense scrutiny on how it handles user data, creating a cloud of uncertainty for the company before its public offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is Facebook’s biggest conundrum. As the world’s largest social network, it faces intense scrutiny from consumers, courts and regulators worldwide over how it handles the data it collects from its 845 million users. But as a company preparing to go public, it is under pressure to find new ways to turn that data into profit.

articles.headline: In Attack on Vatican Web Site, a Glimpse of Hackers’ Tactics
articles.snippet: An attack by the hacker group Anonymous on a Vatican Web site in August offers a rare look at the collective’s approach to recruiting, reconnaissance and warfare.
articles.abstract: An attack by the hacker group Anonymous on a Vatican Web site in August offers a rare look at the collective’s approach to recruiting, reconnaissance and warfare.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The elusive hacker movement known as Anonymous has carried out Internet attacks on well-known organizations like Sony and PBS. In August, the group went after its most prominent target yet: the Vatican.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and John Markoff

articles.headline: A Taste of Hope Sends Refugees Back to Darfur
articles.snippet: More than 100,000 people have left the sprawling camps where they took refuge for nearly a decade and headed home to their villages in Darfur over the past year.
articles.abstract: More than 100,000 people have left the sprawling camps where they took refuge for nearly a decade and headed home to their villages in Darfur over the past year.
articles.lead_paragraph: NYURU, Sudan — More than 100,000 people in Darfur have left the sprawling camps where they had taken refuge for nearly a decade and headed home to their villages over the past year, the biggest return of displaced people since the war began in 2003 and a sign that one of the world’s most infamous conflicts may have decisively cooled.

articles.headline: Blurred Line Between Espionage and Truth
articles.snippet: After promising to enhance whistle-blower laws to protect federal workers, the Obama administration has used the Espionage Act as a kind of ad hoc Official Secrets Act.
articles.abstract: After promising to enhance whistle-blower laws to protect federal workers, the Obama administration has used the Espionage Act as a kind of ad hoc Official Secrets Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday in the White House briefing room, the administration’s press secretary, Jay Carney, opened on a somber note, citing the deaths of Marie Colvin and Anthony Shadid, two reporters who had died “in order to bring truth” while reporting in Syria.

articles.headline: Afghan Uproar Casts Shadows on U.S Pullout
articles.snippet: Administration officials described growing concern about a drawdown by the United States that hinges on the close mentoring and training of Afghan army and police forces.
articles.abstract: Administration officials described growing concern about a drawdown by the United States that hinges on the close mentoring and training of Afghan army and police forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American officials sought to reassure both Afghanistan’s government and a domestic audience on Sunday that the United States remained committed to the war after the weekend killing of two American military officers inside the Afghan Interior Ministry and days of deadly anti-American protests.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Opt-Out Provision Would Halt Some, but Not All, Web Tracking
articles.snippet: Advertising and technology industries, which have been under pressure to do more to ensure privacy, said they would support a “Do Not Track” mechanism, yet consumers would hardly be invisible online.
articles.abstract: Advertising and technology industries, which have been under pressure to do more to ensure privacy, said they would support a “Do Not Track” mechanism, yet consumers would hardly be invisible online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Thursday federal regulators, members of advertising trade groups and technology companies gathered in Washington to announce new initiatives to protect consumers’ privacy online.

articles.headline: With Book, Buchanan Set His Fate
articles.snippet: Pat Buchanan’s pessimistic book “Suicide of a Superpower: Will America Survive to 2025?” bemoaned that birthrate trends and “Third World” immigration were precipitating “the end of white America.”
articles.abstract: Pat Buchanan’s pessimistic book “Suicide of a Superpower: Will America Survive to 2025?” bemoaned that birthrate trends and “Third World” immigration were precipitating “the end of white America.”
articles.lead_paragraph: As the conservative polemicist Pat Buchanan prepared last fall for the release of his book “Suicide of a Superpower: Will America Survive to 2025?,” some friends who worked with him at MSNBC were worried. The book, they told him, would provoke controversy and threaten his professional well-being.

articles.headline: Santorum Makes Case for Religion in Public Sphere
articles.snippet: With social concerns gaining prominence in the race, Rick Santorum defended religion’s role in public life, criticizing universities and John F. Kennedy’s famous speech.
articles.abstract: With social concerns gaining prominence in the race, Rick Santorum defended religion’s role in public life, criticizing universities and John F. Kennedy’s famous speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. — With two days left before the high-stakes Republican primaries in Arizona and Michigan, Rick Santorum delivered a full-throated defense of religion in public life on Sunday, appealing to the social conservatives who have revived his presidential campaign.

articles.headline: Across Arizona, Illegal Immigration Is on Back Burner
articles.snippet: Voters appear to be occupied with concerns about the economy and unemployment, and Republican presidential candidates are shying from an issue that could alienate Latino voters.
articles.abstract: Voters appear to be occupied with concerns about the economy and unemployment, and Republican presidential candidates are shying from an issue that could alienate Latino voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANDLER, Ariz. — The angry protests over Arizona’s tough policies focused on illegal immigrants are mostly gone. The sponsor of the state’s touchstone immigration bill has been recalled, while two sheriffs who championed the crackdown are enmeshed in legal difficulties. And there has been a notable decline in police activity aimed at illegal immigrants, easing a long period of anxiety among Mexican communities.

articles.headline: Obama’s Deficit Dilemma
articles.snippet: President Obama was aloof to the proposals of a panel he created, but later adopted many of them in a modified form, a sign of his larger struggle with the politics of deficit reduction.
articles.abstract: President Obama was aloof to the proposals of a panel he created, but later adopted many of them in a modified form, a sign of his larger struggle with the politics of deficit reduction.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama was backstage at an auditorium at George Washington University last April preparing to give a major speech, when William M. Daley, then his chief of staff, spied an unexpected guest in the audience: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican chairman of the House Budget Committee, whose budget plan Mr. Obama was about to shred.

articles.headline: A Fresh Blot on Murdoch’s Sun
articles.snippet: A top investigator said Rupert Murdoch’s Sun newspaper had paid British officials large sums for information.
articles.abstract: A top investigator said Rupert Murdoch’s Sun newspaper had paid British officials large sums for information.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A day after presiding over the publication of his new, damn-the-critics Sun on Sunday tabloid, Rupert Murdoch was confronted with fresh allegations from a top police investigator that the daily Sun had systematically paid large sums of money to “a network of corrupted officials” in the British police, military and government.
